questions.text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after he sustained an injury to his right hand while playing basketball. The ball hit his right index finger with force and he is now unable to lift the end of the finger. Examination shows a right index finger flexed at the distal interphalangeal joint and inability to actively extend the distal phalanx; range of motion is limited by pain. There is an extension deficit of 10°. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the hand shows no fractures. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Stack splint in hyperextension
Kirschner wire fixation
Intraosseous suturing
Buddy tape to neighboring finger
Tendon suturing

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In uncomplicated extensor digitorum tendon injuries (no associated displaced fractures, extension deficit < 45°), a stack splint is used to stabilize the joint for 6–8 weeks in slight hyperextension in order to achieve a close approximation of the tendon ends and full recovery. When applying splints to areas with bony protuberances, as in this case, excessive direct pressure from the splint must be avoided. Continuous pressure can lead to skin necrosis and subsequent healing disorders and infections.
Image Description:

Right middle finger with extended PIP and flexed DIP joints

This condition results from sudden forced hyperflexion of the DIP joint while the digit is extended (particularly common in sports such as basketball and baseball), which causes rupture or avulsion of the extensor digitorum tendon.

B) INCORRECT:

Kirschner wires are used to fixate bone fragments, particularly in fractures of smaller bones. As this patient most likely has an extensor tendon injury and shows no signs of fractures on x-ray, Kirschner wire fixation is unnecessary at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

While a concomitant avulsion fracture can occur in extensor tendon injuries, it only requires intraosseous suturing in select cases, as the distal interphalangeal joint is a non-weight-bearing joint and articular incongruities often heal well or are well-tolerated. Additionally, this patient's x-ray shows no signs of an associated fracture.

D) INCORRECT:

Buddy taping is used for minor finger or toe injuries (e.g., nondisplaced stable fractures, sprains, dislocations) if the damaged digit requires immobilization. This treatment is not the most appropriate for an acute mallet finger because it cannot ensure the ideal recovery position. In certain patients with mallet finger who need additional finger protection (e.g., athletes returning to sports, individuals with jobs that involve heavy lifting), buddy taping may be considered after initial therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical treatment of mallet finger is rarely required and only indicated in patients with severe fractures, subluxation of the joint, failure of conservative treatment, or in patients who cannot wear a splint (e.g., because of their profession). This patient has none of the above indications. Injuries to the flexor digitorum profundus tendon virtually always require surgical treatment. However, such injuries manifest with an inability to actively flex the distal phalanx (Jersey finger).
questions.hint: The flexed distal interphalangeal joint with the inability to actively extend the distal phalanx after direct trauma to the finger suggests an extensor tendon injury (mallet finger).

questions.text: Paramedics are called to a 35-year-old man who has accidentally cut off his left fingertip while chopping vegetables. He has no significant past medical history. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. His left index finger is amputated distal to the distal interphalangeal joint at the level of the nail bed, and exposed bone is visible. There is profuse bleeding from the wound site. His ability to flex, extend, abduct, and adduct the joints is preserved and sensation is intact. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for preserving the detached fingertip prior to transporting this patient to the emergency department?

choices.text: Wrap the fingertip in gauze wet with iodine in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice
Wrap the fingertip in dry gauze in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice
Preserve the fingertip in cooled saline water
Preserve the fingertip in warm saline water
Wrap the fingertip in gauze damp with saline in a sealed plastic bag placed in ice water
Place the fingertip on ice in a sealed plastic bag
Wrap the fingertip in gauze wet with hydrogen peroxide in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice
Wrap the fingertip in gauze wet with alcohol in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although wrapping the fingertip in damp gauze, sealing it in a plastic bag, then placing it on ice is an appropriate approach for preserving an amputated fingertip, antiseptics such as iodine damage the finger tissue and decrease tissue viability, reducing the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).

B) INCORRECT:

The fingertip should be wrapped in gauze, sealed in a plastic bag, and then placed on ice. However, dry gauze is not recommended because it compromises tissue integrity and decreases the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).

C) INCORRECT:

Although the fingertip should be kept cool during transport, direct immersion in saline water is not recommended as it may cause maceration of tissue and decrease the likelihood of successful reattachment (replantation).

D) INCORRECT:

Warm saline water is not recommended as it may cause maceration (due to direct immersion in fluid) of open tissue and encourage microbial growth in the wound (by warming), both of which would decrease the likelihood of reattachment (replantation).

E) CORRECT:

The amputated fingertip should be gently rinsed with water, wrapped in damp gauze, sealed in a watertight bag, and then placed in a bag with ice water. An amputated limb should never be placed directly on ice because of the potential for cold damage (i.e., frostbite). The aim is to preserve the finger as best as possible in order to maximize the chances of successful reattachment (replantation). The patient and their amputated fingertip should then be transported immediately to the emergency department.

Once in the emergency department, the patient's hand would be anesthetized and debrided. The decision to attempt reattachment is typically left to specialist consultation and is decided on a case-by-case basis, although it is not commonly attempted in adults.

F) INCORRECT:

Directly placing the fingertip on ice is not recommended because of the risk of cold damage (i.e., frostbite).

G) INCORRECT:

Although wrapping the fingertip in damp gauze, sealing it in a plastic bag, then placing it on ice is an appropriate approach for preserving an amputated fingertip, antiseptics such as hydrogen peroxide damage the finger tissue and decrease tissue viability, reducing the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).

H) INCORRECT:

Although wrapping the fingertip in damp gauze, sealing it in a plastic bag, then placing it on ice is an appropriate approach for preserving an amputated fingertip, antiseptics such as alcohol damage the finger tissue and decrease tissue viability, reducing the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).
questions.hint: In complete fingertip amputations, a specific first-aid technique is recommended to preserve the amputated tissue without causing cellular damage.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a progressive swelling and pain in his right ring finger for the past 2 days. The pain began while playing football, when his finger got caught in the jersey of another player who forcefully pulled away. Examination shows that the right ring finger is extended. There is pain and swelling at the distal interphalangeal joint. When the patient is asked to make a fist, his right ring finger does not flex at the distal interphalangeal joint. There is no joint laxity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion
Closed fracture of the distal phalanx
Rupture of the extensor digitorum tendon at its point of insertion
Inflammation of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon sheath
Slipping of the central band of the extensor digitorum tendon

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendon, also known as “jersey finger,” is a common sports injury and most commonly affects the right ring finger. The FDP, along with the flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS), is responsible for finger flexion. The tendons from the FDP muscle run through the carpal tunnel and insert on the palmar side of the distal phalanges of each finger, whereas the FDS tendons insert on the middle phalanx. This patient's inability to flex the DIP combined with the pain over the DIP joint, which is distal to the attachment of the FDS, indicate that he has ruptured his FDP tendon.
Image Description:

The extensor tendons are connected by the intertendinous connection. Annular ligaments stabilize the flexor tendons, which cross one another. The superficial flexor tendons attach to the middle phalanx and the deep flexor tendons to the distal phalanx.

B) INCORRECT:

The distal phalanges are the most commonly fractured bones in the hand. Distal phalanx fracture is a common sports-related injury, but it would present with pain over the phalanx itself, rather than over one of the interphalangeal joints. While deformity of the distal phalanx and nail is common with distal phalanx fractures, a specific deficit in either flexion or extension over a particular joint would be less common.

C) INCORRECT:

The extensor digitorum (ED) tendons extend the fingers of the hand. Rupture of the ED tendons leads to a pathology known as “mallet finger” or “baseball finger.” This injury often occurs when a ball hits the tip of the finger and hyperflexes the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP). Patients with this injury would be unable to extend the DIP of the affected finger and would likely have more pain on the dorsal aspect of the finger over the DIP.
Image Description:

X-ray finger (lateral view) of a patient with inability to extend finger after trauma

An avulsion fracture of the dorsal aspect of the base of the distal phalanx (green overlay) shows intraarticular extension into the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. The injury to the extensor mechanism has resulted in a flexion deformity (indicated by arrow and lines) at the DIP joint (mallet finger).

Mallet finger may be an isolated tendinous injury or may occur in combination with an avulsion fracture of the dorsal base of the distal phalanx of a finger.

D) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the flexor tendon sheath is a condition known as “trigger finger.” The inflammation causes a stenosing tenosynovitis that leads to a locking or catching sensation during active flexion-extension activity, which can progress to the extent that the digit can only be extended through passive manipulation. Patients may also have a palpable nodule along the axis of the flexor tendon. The cause of trigger finger is unknown but may be related to repeated digital flexion.

E) INCORRECT:

Slipping or disruption of the central band of the extensor digitorum (ED) tendon is a condition known as Boutonniere deformity. This can be caused by sharp or blunt trauma, such as jamming a finger in a door. It can also be caused by rheumatoid arthritis, in which case the inflammation of the joint space pushes the central band of the ED out of its normal anatomical position. Patients with Boutonniere deformity present with hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal joint and flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joint.
questions.hint: This patient's injury is a common sports injury caused by forceful hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP).

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy who is right-hand dominant presents with pain in his right ring finger after injuring it while playing football last night. He felt a pop when his finger got caught on his opponent’s jersey as he reached out to tackle him.
He has tenderness to palpation and swelling on the volar aspect of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint of his right ring finger. He is able to extend his DIP joint but cannot actively flex it. Vascular and neurologic examinations of the hand are normal.
A radiograph is obtained (figure).
In addition to arranging appropriate follow-up, what is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Splint the distal interphalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints in slight flexion
Recommend ice, compression, elevation, and early range-of-motion exercises
Obtain an MRI of the hand
Splint the distal interphalangeal joint in extension
Buddy-tape the third and fourth fingers

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Jersey finger is a term used to describe injury of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon where it attaches to the distal phalanx. This injury occurs as a result of forced extension against a flexed finger, most often during a tackling sport. The ring finger is most commonly affected.

Absence of active flexion at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint indicates a complete tear, whereas weakness with flexion is more likely to be a partial tear. There may also be an associated avulsion fracture of the distal phalanx, as shown with the arrow in this radiograph.

Partial and complete tears of the flexor digitorum profundus both require surgical repair; they should be splinted in slight flexion and promptly referred to a hand surgeon for definitive management.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management of an injury to the flexor digitorum profundus tendon (jersey finger) is to splint the distal interphalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints in slight flexion.

B) INCORRECT:

Ice, compression, elevation, and exercises is not appropriate for this injury. Without surgery, the patient can develop chronic pain, stiffness, instability, permanent weakness, and inability to flex the finger.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI is not typically indicated for jersey finger, unless the diagnosis is unclear or chronic injuries ensue.

D) INCORRECT:

Splinting the joint in extension would be appropriate if the patient had a rupture of the extensor mechanism at the DIP joint (mallet finger). This injury is characterized by pain over the distal phalanx and an inability to actively achieve full extension of the DIP.

E) INCORRECT:

Buddy-taping the fingers or recommending other conservative approaches (such as ice, compression, elevation, and exercises) is not appropriate for this injury. Without surgery, the patient can develop chronic pain, stiffness, instability, permanent weakness, and inability to flex the finger.

questions.text: You are seeing a 19-year-old man in the emergency department 2 hours after he injured his right hand while playing basketball. On examination, his right index finger is flexed at the distal interphalangeal joint, and he cannot actively extend the distal phalanx. Range of motion is limited by pain, and there is a 10° extension deficit. The rest of the examination is normal. An x-ray of the hand shows no fractures. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intraosseous suturing.
Buddy tape to neighboring finger.
Stack splint in hyperextension.
Tendon suturing.
Kirschner wire fixation.

A) INCORRECT:

While a concomitant avulsion fracture can occur in extensor tendon injuries, it only requires intraosseous suturing in select cases, as the distal interphalangeal joint is a non-weight-bearing joint and articular incongruities often heal well or are well-tolerated. Additionally, this patient's x-ray shows no signs of an associated fracture.

When applying splints to areas with bony protuberances, as in this case, excessive direct pressure from the splint must be avoided. Image Description:

Right middle finger with extended PIP and flexed DIP joints

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 4 hours after striking her left ring finger with a hammer while putting furniture together. She reports severe, throbbing pain that worsens when the finger is held downward. An image of the patient's finger is shown. The nail plate remains intact and firmly adherent. Capillary refill is normal, and there is no evidence of active bleeding. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Immediate hand surgery consultation
Nail trephination
Nail plate removal for inspection
Splinting with outpatient follow-up
Digital nerve block and observation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hand surgery consultation is not required for simple subungual hematoma drainage, which can be performed in the emergency department. Consultation is appropriate for complex nail bed lacerations or fractures requiring surgical repair.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Nail trephination is indicated for subungual hematomas covering greater than 50% of the nail bed to decompress the hematoma and provide pain relief. The procedure involves creating 2–3 holes in the nail plate using electrocautery or an 18-gauge needle. This patient's approx. 70% coverage clearly meets the threshold for intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Nail plate removal is not indicated for subungual hematoma drainage when the nail is adherent and intact. Adherent nails do not need to be removed to drain a subungual hematoma, and removal causes unnecessary trauma and delays healing.

D) INCORRECT:

Conservative management with splinting alone is insufficient for large subungual hematomas covering greater than 50% of the nail bed. Without decompression, this patient will continue to experience severe pain and risk complications from increased pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

While a digital nerve block may be used for procedural pain management during trephination, observation alone is inappropriate for a large subungual hematoma. This patient requires active decompression to relieve pain and prevent complications.

questions.text: A 24-year-old mechanic presents after crushing his middle finger in a hydraulic press. Examination shows a 3-cm nail bed laceration with complete nail avulsion and an underlying nondisplaced transverse fracture of the distal phalanx. Digital nerve block, nail removal, irrigation, debridement, and nail bed repair with 6-0 absorbable sutures are performed. The avulsed nail plate is intact but has a 1-cm longitudinal crack. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Apply tissue adhesive directly to the nail bed
Place a rigid fingertip splint over the exposed nail bed
Reapply the intact portions of the nail plate as a splint
Repair the cracked nail plate with 4-0 sutures before reapplication
Apply nonadherent gauze over the nail bed

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tissue adhesive is used to secure the nail plate to the surrounding tissue after reapplication, not applied directly to the nail bed. The nail bed has already been repaired with sutures, and the next step involves managing the nail plate.

B) INCORRECT:

Rigid fingertip splints are not the primary treatment for nail bed injuries. The reapplied nail plate itself serves as a splint. Additional rigid splinting is generally unnecessary unless there are specific fracture considerations.

C) INCORRECT:

A cracked nail plate loses its structural integrity and cannot effectively protect the underlying tissue. Reapplying it without repair compromises its function as a splint.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- The cracked nail plate should be repaired with 4-0 sutures on a sturdy needle before reapplication. Once repaired, the nail plate can serve as both a splint and a biological dressing.

E) INCORRECT:

Although nonadherent gauze can be used when the nail plate is not available or is severely damaged, this patient's nail plate is intact and can provide superior protection and splinting function than gauze alone.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the ED after injuring her index finger during a basketball game. She reports falling onto her outstretched hand and feeling immediate pain. Examination shows approximately 70° hyperextension of the proximal phalanx, pain and swelling at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint, and absence of a palmar dimple. X-rays show dorsal dislocation of the index finger MCP joint with articular surfaces in partial contact. After performing closed reduction, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain CT scan
Splint in 60° of flexion
Buddy taping without splinting
Splint in 30° of flexion
Immobilize in extension

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Standard radiographs are sufficient to diagnose and assess the degree of dislocation and articular alignment of simple MCP dislocations.

B) CORRECT:

Simple dorsal MCP dislocations should be immobilized in approximately 60° of flexion for 7 days after closed reduction. This position optimizes joint stability, prevents hyperextension, and promotes proper healing. The clinical findings of hyperextension between 60° and 90°, partial articular contact, and absence of a palmar dimple are consistent with a simple dislocation suitable for this management.

C) INCORRECT:

Buddy taping alone does not provide sufficient immobilization immediately after MCP dislocation reduction. Initial immobilization with a flexion splint is necessary to maintain joint stability before transitioning to buddy taping during rehabilitation.

D) INCORRECT:

Splinting in 30° of flexion is appropriate for interphalangeal joint injuries. MCP joint dislocations indicate a greater degree of flexion to maintain stability and prevent recurrence.

E) INCORRECT:

Immobilizing the finger in extension after dislocation is contraindicated, as it fails to stabilize the joint and increases the risk of redislocation. Flexion positioning is essential for all finger dislocations after reduction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man who is a painter presents after jamming his right middle finger in a door. He reports immediate pain and swelling but continued working for several hours. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness over the middle phalanx with a normal finger cascade. X-rays show a transverse fracture through the middle phalanx with no angular deformity or shortening. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Finger cage splint for 3–4 weeks
Dynamic splinting with buddy taping
Closed reduction followed by volar splinting
Ulnar gutter splint with hand surgery consultation
Dorsal aluminum splint with metacarpophalangeal joint at 70-90° flexion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Finger cage splints are indicated for distal phalangeal fractures, particularly tuft fractures and nondisplaced distal phalanx fractures, but not for middle phalanx fractures.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- For nondisplaced transverse fractures of the middle phalanx without angulation, shortening, or rotational deformity, the standard treatment is dynamic splinting with buddy taping for 2–3 weeks. This approach promotes healing while maintaining joint mobility and minimizing stiffness.

C) INCORRECT:

Closed reduction is not indicated for nondisplaced fractures without deformity. Volar splinting is typically used for displaced distal phalanx fractures after reduction, not for middle phalanx fractures.

D) INCORRECT:

Ulnar gutter splinting with hand surgery consultation is reserved for displaced transverse fractures of the middle phalanx with angulation, shortening, or rotational deformity.

E) INCORRECT:

This splinting technique is indicated for nondisplaced transverse fractures of the proximal phalanx, not for middle phalanx fractures.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man who is a chef presents after accidentally cutting the tip of his left ring finger with a mandoline slicer. Examination shows amputation beyond the flexor digitorum profundus insertion with < 1 cm2 soft tissue loss, minimal bone exposure, and an intact nail bed. Capillary refill and distal sensation are normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Irrigation, debridement, and loose closure with outpatient follow-up
Apply tourniquet and prepare for emergency surgical repair
Trim exposed bone and allow healing by secondary intention
Place amputated tissue in saline-moistened gauze and ice bath
Immediate hand surgery consultation for potential replantation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Small distal fingertip amputations with an intact nail, minimal to no bone exposure, and soft tissue loss < 1 cm2 can be treated in the emergency department with irrigation, debridement of nonviable tissue, and loose closure if feasible. When the injury is distal to tendon insertions and meets these criteria, immediate hand surgery consultation is not necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Tourniquets should be avoided in finger amputations because they increase the risk of local thromboembolic events. Direct pressure is usually sufficient for hemostasis.

C) INCORRECT:

While limited bone trimming may be required, viable tissue should be preserved. Over-aggressive excision of bone or soft tissue sacrifices length and function; another step should be attempted first.

D) INCORRECT:

This tissue preservation technique is indicated for proximal amputations that may require replantation, not for small distal tuft avulsions that can be managed conservatively in the emergency department.

E) INCORRECT:

Most distal amputations require hand surgery consultation, but small tuft avulsions with an intact nail, minimal bone exposure, and soft tissue loss of < 1 cm2 can be managed in the emergency department without immediate specialist consultation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents after injuring his ring finger during a basketball game. He reports pain when his finger was forcefully straightened while attempting to steal the ball. Examination shows swelling over the palmar aspect of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint and difficulty making a complete fist with that finger. The proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint has normal range of motion. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Splint the DIP joint in extension
Splint the PIP joint in extension
Apply a volar splint to the entire finger
Splint the finger with a dorsal splint
Recommend buddy taping and early mobilization

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

DIP extension splinting is the appropriate treatment for mallet finger. This patient’s inability to flex the DIP joint and palmar swelling indicate a flexor tendon injury (jersey finger).

B) INCORRECT:

PIP extension splinting treats boutonniere deformity, which is an extensor injury causing PIP flexion and DIP hyperextension. This patient has normal PIP motion and impaired DIP flexion, so boutonniere deformity is unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Volar splints place the flexor tendons under tension and worsen flexor tendon injuries.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- The mechanism of injury, palmar DIP swelling, and inability to fully flex are consistent with jersey finger (flexor digitorum profundus avulsion). Dorsal splinting protects the injured flexor tendon by keeping the finger extended and minimizing tension on the tendon until surgical repair can be performed.

E) INCORRECT:

Flexor tendon injuries do not heal well with conservative treatment. Buddy taping and early mobilization risk permanent loss of DIP flexion and functional impairment.

questions.text: A 25-year-old athlete presents with finger pain following a sports injury. Examination reveals inability to flex the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint of the ring finger while the finger is extended at rest. There is mild swelling and tenderness over the palmar DIP joint. Neurovascular examination is normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Dorsal splint and urgent hand surgery referral
Volar splint and outpatient follow-up
Buddy taping and return to play
MRI to evaluate tendon integrity
X-ray and discharge with NSAIDs

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation is consistent with jersey finger (flexor digitorum profundus rupture), and operative repair is indicated. Immobilization in a dorsal splint and hand surgery referral within 7 days optimizes outcomes.

B) INCORRECT:

Volar splinting is not appropriate for flexor tendon ruptures. Outpatient follow-up without surgery risks permanent functional loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Buddy taping is appropriate for minor sprains with preserved function. This patient's presentation suggests complete tendon rupture, and premature return to play risks worsening injury.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI is not routinely required for the diagnosis of jersey finger. Immediate immobilization and timely surgical referral take precedence over imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

X-rays can help exclude avulsion fractures but cannot be used to diagnose tendon ruptures. Discharging with only NSAIDs and no referral risks permanent disability and joint contractures.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents 3 hours after catching his middle finger in a crack while attempting to arrest a fall during rock climbing. He reports immediate pain and inability to grip properly. Examination shows mild swelling at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint and normal neurovascular status. The finger appears extended at rest. He cannot flex the DIP joint when asked to make a fist, while the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) flexion remain intact. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Buddy tape the injured finger to the adjacent digit
Apply dorsal splint and arrange hand surgery follow-up within one week
Apply DIP extension splint for 6–8 weeks and arrange orthopedic follow-up
Schedule urgent hand surgery consultation within 24 hours
Obtain radiographs to exclude fracture before treatment

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Buddy taping may be appropriate for minor sprains or stable fractures. It does not adequately immobilize the DIP joint in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – Isolated loss of DIP flexion with intact PIP and MCP function is diagnostic of jersey finger (flexor digitorum profundus tendon rupture); imaging can be deferred in favor of splinting and hand surgery referral. Operative repair should be performed within 7–10 days.

C) INCORRECT:

A DIP extension splint is appropriate management for mallet finger (extensor tendon injury). This patient's injury is consistent with jersey finger, not mallet finger.

D) INCORRECT:

Urgent consultation is reserved for open injury or neurovascular compromise. This patient's injury is consistent with jersey finger, and urgent consultation is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Radiographs may show associated avulsion fractures but are not required before initial management when clinical findings clearly indicate jersey finger. The inability to flex the DIP joint with normal PIP function is diagnostic.
